question: Question_06_(b)
sols:
Using our answer from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_06_(a)}{part
(a)}, we can write I with the given \emph{$f$} as

\begin{align*}I = \int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\,dydx.\end{align*} We
can evaluate the integral as follows:

\begin{align*}
I &= \int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\,dydx \\
&= \int_{-1}^{2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\left(x + 2 - x^{2} \right)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-1}^{2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}(-x + 2)(x + 1)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-1}^{2}\exp(x)(x + 1)\,dx.\end{align*} Using integration by parts, with \emph{u=x+1} and \emph{dv
= exp(x)},

\begin{align*}
I &= \int_{-1}^{2}\exp(x)(x + 1)\,dx \\
&= \exp(x)(x + 1)\Big\vert_{-1}^{2} - \int_{-1}^{2}\exp(x)\,dx \\
&= 3\exp(2) - \left(\exp(x)\Big\vert_{-1}^{2}\right) = 2\exp(2) + \exp(-1)\end{align*} Therefore,

\begin{align*}{\color{blue}\int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\,dydx = 2e^{2} + e^{-1}
}\end{align*}
hints:
Using the solution of
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_06_(a)}{part
(a)}, we calculate the integral

$\displaystyle \int_{-1}^2\int_{x^2}^{x+2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2-x}\;\text{d}y\text{d}x$

It make sense to use the order of integration, where we first integrate
with respect to $\displaystyle y$, since integration with respect to
$\displaystyle x$ first is very hard with this integrand.

After integration with respect to $\displaystyle y$, you need to
integrate

\begin{align*}\displaystyle \int_{-1}^{2}\frac{\exp(x)}{2 - x}\left(x + 2 - x^{2} \right)\text{d}x\end{align*}

Factorize the term in the brackets, then use integration by parts.
